trans-unit.source: Advanced Analytics Process and Technology in Action: using HDInsight Hadoop clusters on the 1 TB Criteo dataset | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Advanced Analytics Process and Technology in Action: using HDInsight Hadoop clusters on the 1 TB Criteo dataset | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Using the Advanced Analytics Process and Technology (ADAPT) for an end-to-end scenario employing an HDInsight Hadoop cluster to build and deploy a model using a large (1 TB) publicly available dataset
trans-unit.target: Using the Advanced Analytics Process and Technology (ADAPT) for an end-to-end scenario employing an HDInsight Hadoop cluster to build and deploy a model using a large (1 TB) publicly available dataset

trans-unit.source: In this walkthrough, we demonstrate using the Advanced Analytics Process and Technology (ADAPT) end-to-end with an <linkText>Azure HDInsight Hadoop cluster</linkText><title></title> to store, explore, feature engineer, and down sample data from one of the publicly available <linkText>Criteo</linkText><title></title> datasets.
trans-unit.target: In this walkthrough, we demonstrate using the Advanced Analytics Process and Technology (ADAPT) end-to-end with an <linkText>Azure HDInsight Hadoop cluster</linkText><title></title> to store, explore, feature engineer, and down sample data from one of the publicly available <linkText>Criteo</linkText><title></title> datasets.

trans-unit.source: We use Azure Machine Learning to build a binary classification model on this data.
trans-unit.target: We use Azure Machine Learning to build a binary classification model on this data.

trans-unit.source: We also show how to publish one of these models as a Web service.
trans-unit.target: We also show how to publish one of these models as a Web service.

trans-unit.source: It is also possible to use an IPython notebook to accomplish the tasks presented in this walkthrough.
trans-unit.target: It is also possible to use an IPython notebook to accomplish the tasks presented in this walkthrough.

trans-unit.source: Users who would like to try this approach should consult the <linkText>Criteo walkthrough using a Hive ODBC connection</linkText><title></title> topic.
trans-unit.target: Users who would like to try this approach should consult the <linkText>Criteo walkthrough using a Hive ODBC connection</linkText><title></title> topic.

trans-unit.source: The Criteo data is a click prediction dataset that is approximately 370GB of gzip compressed TSV files (~1.3TB uncompressed), comprising more than 4.3 billion records.
trans-unit.target: The Criteo data is a click prediction dataset that is approximately 370GB of gzip compressed TSV files (~1.3TB uncompressed), comprising more than 4.3 billion records.

trans-unit.source: It is taken from 24 days of click data made available by <linkText>Criteo</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: It is taken from 24 days of click data made available by <linkText>Criteo</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For the convenience of data scientists, we have unzipped data available to us to experiment with.
trans-unit.target: For the convenience of data scientists, we have unzipped data available to us to experiment with.

trans-unit.source: Each record in this dataset contains 40 columns:
trans-unit.target: Each record in this dataset contains 40 columns:

trans-unit.source: the first column is a label column that indicates whether a user clicks on an add (value 1) or does not click (value 0)
trans-unit.target: the first column is a label column that indicates whether a user clicks on an add (value 1) or does not click (value 0)

trans-unit.source: next 13 columns are numeric, and
trans-unit.target: next 13 columns are numeric, and

trans-unit.source: last 26 are categorical columns
trans-unit.target: last 26 are categorical columns

trans-unit.source: The columns are anonymized and use a series of enumerated names: "Col1" (for the label column) to 'Col40" (for the last categorical column).
trans-unit.target: The columns are anonymized and use a series of enumerated names: "Col1" (for the label column) to 'Col40" (for the last categorical column).

trans-unit.source: Here is an excerpt of the first 20 columns of two observations (rows) from this dataset:
trans-unit.target: Here is an excerpt of the first 20 columns of two observations (rows) from this dataset:

trans-unit.source: There are missing values in both the numeric and categorical columns in this dataset.
trans-unit.target: There are missing values in both the numeric and categorical columns in this dataset.

trans-unit.source: We describe a simple method for handling the missing values below.
trans-unit.target: We describe a simple method for handling the missing values below.

trans-unit.source: Additional details of the data are explored below when we store them into Hive tables.
trans-unit.target: Additional details of the data are explored below when we store them into Hive tables.

trans-unit.source: Definition: Clickthrough rate (CTR): This is the percentage of clicks in the data.
trans-unit.target: Definition: Clickthrough rate (CTR): This is the percentage of clicks in the data.

trans-unit.source: In this Criteo dataset, the CTR is about 3.3% or 0.033.
trans-unit.target: In this Criteo dataset, the CTR is about 3.3% or 0.033.

trans-unit.source: Two sample prediction problems are addressed in this walkthrough:
trans-unit.target: Two sample prediction problems are addressed in this walkthrough:

trans-unit.source: Binary classification: Predicts whether or not a user clicked on an add:
trans-unit.target: Binary classification: Predicts whether or not a user clicked on an add:

trans-unit.source: Class 0: No Click
trans-unit.target: Class 0: No Click

trans-unit.source: Class 1: Click
trans-unit.target: Class 1: Click

trans-unit.source: Regression: Predicts the probability of an ad click from user features.
trans-unit.target: Regression: Predicts the probability of an ad click from user features.

trans-unit.source: Note: This is typically an Admin task.
trans-unit.target: Note: This is typically an Admin task.

trans-unit.source: Set up your Azure Data Science environment for building predictive analytics solutions with HDInsight clusters in three steps:
trans-unit.target: Set up your Azure Data Science environment for building predictive analytics solutions with HDInsight clusters in three steps:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a storage account</linkText><title></title>: This storage account is used to store data in Azure Blob Storage.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a storage account</linkText><title></title>: This storage account is used to store data in Azure Blob Storage.

trans-unit.source: The data used in HDInsight clusters is stored here.
trans-unit.target: The data used in HDInsight clusters is stored here.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Customize Azure HDInsight Hadoop Clusters for Data Science</linkText><title></title>: This step creates an Azure HDInsight Hadoop cluster with 64-bit Anaconda Python 2.7 installed on all nodes.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Customize Azure HDInsight Hadoop Clusters for Data Science</linkText><title></title>: This step creates an Azure HDInsight Hadoop cluster with 64-bit Anaconda Python 2.7 installed on all nodes.

trans-unit.source: There are two important steps (described in this topic) to complete when customizing the HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: There are two important steps (described in this topic) to complete when customizing the HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: You must link the storage account created in step 1 with your HDInsight cluster when it is created.
trans-unit.target: You must link the storage account created in step 1 with your HDInsight cluster when it is created.

trans-unit.source: This storage account is used for accessing data that can be processed within the cluster.
trans-unit.target: This storage account is used for accessing data that can be processed within the cluster.

trans-unit.source: You must enable Remote Access to the head node of the cluster after it is created.
trans-unit.target: You must enable Remote Access to the head node of the cluster after it is created.

trans-unit.source: Remember the remote access credentials you specify here (different from those specified for the cluster at its creation): you will need them below.
trans-unit.target: Remember the remote access credentials you specify here (different from those specified for the cluster at its creation): you will need them below.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create an Azure ML workspace</linkText><title></title>: This Azure Machine Learning workspace is used for building machine learning models after an initial data exploration and down sampling on the HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create an Azure ML workspace</linkText><title></title>: This Azure Machine Learning workspace is used for building machine learning models after an initial data exploration and down sampling on the HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>Criteo</linkText><title></title> dataset can be accessed by clicking on the link, accepting the terms of use, and providing a name.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>Criteo</linkText><title></title> dataset can be accessed by clicking on the link, accepting the terms of use, and providing a name.

trans-unit.source: A snapshot of what this looks like is shown below:
trans-unit.target: A snapshot of what this looks like is shown below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Accept Criteo terms</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Accept Criteo terms</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click on Continue to Download to read more about the dataset and its availability.
trans-unit.target: Click on Continue to Download to read more about the dataset and its availability.

trans-unit.source: The data resides in a public <linkText>Azure blob storage</linkText><title></title> location: wasb://criteo@azuremlsampleexperiments.blob.core.windows.net/raw/.
trans-unit.target: The data resides in a public <linkText>Azure blob storage</linkText><title></title> location: wasb://criteo@azuremlsampleexperiments.blob.core.windows.net/raw/.

trans-unit.source: The "wasb" refers to Azure Blob Storage location.
trans-unit.target: The "wasb" refers to Azure Blob Storage location.

trans-unit.source: The data in this public blob storage consists of three sub-folders of unzipped data.
trans-unit.target: The data in this public blob storage consists of three sub-folders of unzipped data.

trans-unit.source: The sub-folder raw/count/ contains the first 21 days of data - from day\00 to day\20
trans-unit.target: The sub-folder raw/count/ contains the first 21 days of data - from day\00 to day\20

trans-unit.source: The sub-folder raw/train/ consists of a single day of data, day\_21
trans-unit.target: The sub-folder raw/train/ consists of a single day of data, day\_21

trans-unit.source: The sub-folder raw/test/ consists of two days of data, day\22 and day\23
trans-unit.target: The sub-folder raw/test/ consists of two days of data, day\22 and day\23

trans-unit.source: For those who want to start with the raw gzip data, these are also available in the main folder raw/ as day_NN.gz, where NN goes from 00 to 23.
trans-unit.target: For those who want to start with the raw gzip data, these are also available in the main folder raw/ as day_NN.gz, where NN goes from 00 to 23.

trans-unit.source: An alternative approach to access, explore, and model this data that does not require any local downloads is explained later in this walkthrough when we create Hive tables.
trans-unit.target: An alternative approach to access, explore, and model this data that does not require any local downloads is explained later in this walkthrough when we create Hive tables.

trans-unit.source: To login to the headnode of the cluster, use the <linkText>Azure Management</linkText><title></title> portal to locate the cluster.
trans-unit.target: To login to the headnode of the cluster, use the <linkText>Azure Management</linkText><title></title> portal to locate the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Click on the HDInsight elephant icon on the left and then double click on the name of your cluster.
trans-unit.target: Click on the HDInsight elephant icon on the left and then double click on the name of your cluster.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the Configuration tab, double click on the CONNECT icon on the bottom of the page, and enter your remote access credentials when prompted.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the Configuration tab, double click on the CONNECT icon on the bottom of the page, and enter your remote access credentials when prompted.

trans-unit.source: This takes you to the headnode of the cluster.
trans-unit.target: This takes you to the headnode of the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Here is what a typical first login to the cluster headnode looks like:
trans-unit.target: Here is what a typical first login to the cluster headnode looks like:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Login to cluster</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Login to cluster</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the left, we see the "Hadoop Command Line", which will be our workhorse for the data exploration.
trans-unit.target: On the left, we see the "Hadoop Command Line", which will be our workhorse for the data exploration.

trans-unit.source: We also see two useful URLs - "Hadoop Yarn Status" and "Hadoop Name Node".
trans-unit.target: We also see two useful URLs - "Hadoop Yarn Status" and "Hadoop Name Node".

trans-unit.source: The yarn status URL shows job progress and the name node URL gives details on the cluster configuration.
trans-unit.target: The yarn status URL shows job progress and the name node URL gives details on the cluster configuration.

trans-unit.source: Now we are set up and ready to begin first part of the walkthrough: data exploration using Hive and getting data ready for Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: Now we are set up and ready to begin first part of the walkthrough: data exploration using Hive and getting data ready for Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: To create Hive tables for our Criteo dataset, open the *Hadoop Command Line* on the desktop of the head node, and enter the Hive directory by entering the command
trans-unit.target: To create Hive tables for our Criteo dataset, open the *Hadoop Command Line* on the desktop of the head node, and enter the Hive directory by entering the command

trans-unit.source: IMPORTANT NOTE: **Run all Hive commands in this walkthrough from the above Hive bin/ directory prompt.
trans-unit.target: IMPORTANT NOTE: **Run all Hive commands in this walkthrough from the above Hive bin/ directory prompt.

trans-unit.source: This will take care of any path issues automatically.
trans-unit.target: This will take care of any path issues automatically.

trans-unit.source: We will use the terms "Hive directory prompt", "Hive bin/ directory prompt", and "Hadoop Command Line" interchangeably.**
trans-unit.target: We will use the terms "Hive directory prompt", "Hive bin/ directory prompt", and "Hadoop Command Line" interchangeably.**

trans-unit.source: IMPORTANT NOTE 2: To execute any Hive query, one can always do the following cd %hive_home%\bin hive
trans-unit.target: IMPORTANT NOTE 2: To execute any Hive query, one can always do the following cd %hive_home%\bin hive

trans-unit.source: After the Hive REPL appears with a "hive >"sign, simply cut and paste the query to execute it.
trans-unit.target: After the Hive REPL appears with a "hive >"sign, simply cut and paste the query to execute it.

trans-unit.source: The code below creates a database "criteo" and then generates 4 tables:
trans-unit.target: The code below creates a database "criteo" and then generates 4 tables:

trans-unit.source: a table for generating counts built on days day\00 to day\20,
trans-unit.target: a table for generating counts built on days day\00 to day\20,

trans-unit.source: a table for use as the train dataset built on day\_21, and
trans-unit.target: a table for use as the train dataset built on day\_21, and

trans-unit.source: two tables for use as the test datasets built on day\22 and day\23 respectively.
trans-unit.target: two tables for use as the test datasets built on day\22 and day\23 respectively.

trans-unit.source: We split our test dataset into two different tables because one of the days is a holiday, and we want to determine if the model can detect differences between a holiday and non-holiday from the clickthrough rate.
trans-unit.target: We split our test dataset into two different tables because one of the days is a holiday, and we want to determine if the model can detect differences between a holiday and non-holiday from the clickthrough rate.

trans-unit.source: The script [sample_hive_create_criteo_database_and_tables.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecreatecriteodatabaseandtables.hql) is displayed below for convenience:
trans-unit.target: The script [sample_hive_create_criteo_database_and_tables.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecreatecriteodatabaseandtables.hql) is displayed below for convenience:

trans-unit.source: We note that all these tables are external as we simply point to Azure Blob Storage (wasb) locations.
trans-unit.target: We note that all these tables are external as we simply point to Azure Blob Storage (wasb) locations.

trans-unit.source: There are two ways to execute ANY Hive query that we now mention.
trans-unit.target: There are two ways to execute ANY Hive query that we now mention.

trans-unit.target: Using the Hive REPL command-line: The first is to issue a "hive" command and copy and paste the above query at the Hive REPL command-line.

trans-unit.target: We begin by counting the number of examples in the train and test data tables.

trans-unit.target: Finally, we examine the number of test examples in the test dataset based on day\_23.

trans-unit.source: The command to do this is similar to the above (refer to [sample_hive_count_criteo_test_day_23_examples.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecountcriteotestday23_examples.hql)):

trans-unit.source: The label distribution in the train dataset is of interest.
trans-unit.target: The label distribution in the train dataset is of interest.

trans-unit.source: To see this, we show contents of [sample_hive_criteo_label_distribution_train_table.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteolabeldistributiontraintable.hql):
trans-unit.target: To see this, we show contents of [sample_hive_criteo_label_distribution_train_table.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteolabeldistributiontraintable.hql):

trans-unit.source: This yields the label distribution:
trans-unit.target: This yields the label distribution:

trans-unit.source: Note that the percentage of positive labels is about 3.3% (consistent with the original dataset).
trans-unit.target: Note that the percentage of positive labels is about 3.3% (consistent with the original dataset).

trans-unit.source: We can use Hive's native "histogram\_numeric" function to find out what the distribution of the numeric variables looks like.
trans-unit.target: We can use Hive's native "histogram\_numeric" function to find out what the distribution of the numeric variables looks like.

trans-unit.source: The contents of [sample_hive_criteo_histogram_numeric.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteohistogramnumeric.hql) are as below:
trans-unit.target: The contents of [sample_hive_criteo_histogram_numeric.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteohistogramnumeric.hql) are as below:

trans-unit.source: This yields the following:
trans-unit.target: This yields the following:

trans-unit.source: The LATERAL VIEW - explode combination in Hive serves to produce a SQL-like output instead of the usual list.
trans-unit.target: The LATERAL VIEW - explode combination in Hive serves to produce a SQL-like output instead of the usual list.

trans-unit.source: Note that in the above table, the first column corresponds to the bin center and the second to the bin frequency.
trans-unit.target: Note that in the above table, the first column corresponds to the bin center and the second to the bin frequency.

trans-unit.source: Also of interest with numeric variables is the computation of approximate percentiles.
trans-unit.target: Also of interest with numeric variables is the computation of approximate percentiles.

trans-unit.source: Hive's native "percentile\_approx" does this for us.
trans-unit.target: Hive's native "percentile\_approx" does this for us.

trans-unit.source: The contents of [sample_hive_criteo_approximate_percentiles.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteoapproximatepercentiles.hql) are:
trans-unit.target: The contents of [sample_hive_criteo_approximate_percentiles.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteoapproximatepercentiles.hql) are:

trans-unit.source: This yields:
trans-unit.target: This yields:

trans-unit.source: We remark that the distribution of percentiles is closely related to the histogram distribution of any numeric variable usually.
trans-unit.target: We remark that the distribution of percentiles is closely related to the histogram distribution of any numeric variable usually.

trans-unit.source: Continuing the data exploration, we now find, for some categorical columns, the number of unique values they take.
trans-unit.target: Continuing the data exploration, we now find, for some categorical columns, the number of unique values they take.

trans-unit.source: To do this, we show contents of [sample_hive_criteo_unique_values_categoricals.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteouniquevalues_categoricals.hql):
trans-unit.target: To do this, we show contents of [sample_hive_criteo_unique_values_categoricals.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteouniquevalues_categoricals.hql):

trans-unit.source: This yields:
trans-unit.target: This yields:

trans-unit.source: We note that Col15 has 19M unique values!
trans-unit.target: We note that Col15 has 19M unique values!

trans-unit.source: Using naive techniques like "one-hot encoding" to encode such high-dimensional categorical variables is infeasible.
trans-unit.target: Using naive techniques like "one-hot encoding" to encode such high-dimensional categorical variables is infeasible.

trans-unit.source: In particular, we explain and demonstrate a powerful, robust technique called <linkText>Learning With Counts</linkText><title></title> for tackling this problem efficiently.
trans-unit.target: In particular, we explain and demonstrate a powerful, robust technique called <linkText>Learning With Counts</linkText><title></title> for tackling this problem efficiently.

trans-unit.source: We end this sub-section by looking at the number of unique values for some other categorical columns as well.
trans-unit.target: We end this sub-section by looking at the number of unique values for some other categorical columns as well.

trans-unit.source: The contents of [sample_hive_criteo_unique_values_multiple_categoricals.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteouniquevaluesmultiplecategoricals.hql) are:
trans-unit.target: The contents of [sample_hive_criteo_unique_values_multiple_categoricals.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteouniquevaluesmultiplecategoricals.hql) are:

trans-unit.source: This yields:
trans-unit.target: This yields:

trans-unit.source: Again we see that except for Col20, all the other columns have many unique values.
trans-unit.target: Again we see that except for Col20, all the other columns have many unique values.

trans-unit.source: The co-occurence counts of pairs of categorical variables is also of interest.
trans-unit.target: The co-occurence counts of pairs of categorical variables is also of interest.

trans-unit.source: This can be determined using the code in [sample_hive_criteo_paired_categorical_counts.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteopairedcategorical_counts.hql):
trans-unit.target: This can be determined using the code in [sample_hive_criteo_paired_categorical_counts.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteopairedcategorical_counts.hql):

trans-unit.source: We reverse order the counts by their occurrence and look at the top 15 in this case.
trans-unit.target: We reverse order the counts by their occurrence and look at the top 15 in this case.

trans-unit.source: This gives us:
trans-unit.target: This gives us:

trans-unit.source: Having explored the datasets and demonstrated how we may do this type of exploration for any variables (including combinations), we now down sample the data sets so that we can build models in Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: Having explored the datasets and demonstrated how we may do this type of exploration for any variables (including combinations), we now down sample the data sets so that we can build models in Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: Recall that the problem we focus on is: given a set of example attributes (feature values from Col2 - Col40), we predict if Col1 is a 0 (no click) or a 1 (click).
trans-unit.target: Recall that the problem we focus on is: given a set of example attributes (feature values from Col2 - Col40), we predict if Col1 is a 0 (no click) or a 1 (click).

trans-unit.source: To down sample our train and test datasets to 1% of the original size, we use Hive's native RAND() function.
trans-unit.target: To down sample our train and test datasets to 1% of the original size, we use Hive's native RAND() function.

trans-unit.source: The next script, [sample_hive_criteo_downsample_train_dataset.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteodownsampletrain_dataset.hql) does this for the train dataset:
trans-unit.target: The next script, [sample_hive_criteo_downsample_train_dataset.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteodownsampletrain_dataset.hql) does this for the train dataset:

trans-unit.source: This yields:
trans-unit.target: This yields:

trans-unit.source: The script [sample_hive_criteo_downsample_test_day_22_dataset.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteodownsampletestday22dataset.hql) does it for test data, day\22:
trans-unit.target: The script [sample_hive_criteo_downsample_test_day_22_dataset.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteodownsampletestday22dataset.hql) does it for test data, day\22:

trans-unit.source: This yields:
trans-unit.target: This yields:

trans-unit.source: Finally, the script [sample_hive_criteo_downsample_test_day_23_dataset.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteodownsampletestday23dataset.hql) does it for test data, day\23:
trans-unit.target: Finally, the script [sample_hive_criteo_downsample_test_day_23_dataset.hql](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/blob/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecriteodownsampletestday23dataset.hql) does it for test data, day\23:

trans-unit.source: This yields:
trans-unit.target: This yields:

trans-unit.source: With this, we are ready to use our down sampled train and test datasets for building models in Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: With this, we are ready to use our down sampled train and test datasets for building models in Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: There is a final important component before we move on to Azure Machine Learning, which is concerns the count table.
trans-unit.target: There is a final important component before we move on to Azure Machine Learning, which is concerns the count table.

trans-unit.source: In the next sub-section, we discuss this in some detail.
trans-unit.target: In the next sub-section, we discuss this in some detail.

trans-unit.source: As we saw, several categorical variables have a very high dimensionality.
trans-unit.target: As we saw, several categorical variables have a very high dimensionality.

trans-unit.source: In our walkthrough, we present a powerful technique called <linkText>Learning With Counts</linkText><title></title> to encode these variables in an efficient, robust manner.
trans-unit.target: In our walkthrough, we present a powerful technique called <linkText>Learning With Counts</linkText><title></title> to encode these variables in an efficient, robust manner.

trans-unit.source: More information on this technique is in the link provided.
trans-unit.target: More information on this technique is in the link provided.

trans-unit.source: Note: In this walkthrough, we focus on using count tables to produce compact representations of high-dimensional categorical features.
trans-unit.target: Note: In this walkthrough, we focus on using count tables to produce compact representations of high-dimensional categorical features.

trans-unit.source: This is certainly not the only way to encode categorical features ; for more information on other techniques, interested users can check out <linkText>one-hot-encoding</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>feature hashing</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This is certainly not the only way to encode categorical features ; for more information on other techniques, interested users can check out <linkText>one-hot-encoding</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>feature hashing</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To build count tables on the count data, we use the data in the folder raw/count.
trans-unit.target: To build count tables on the count data, we use the data in the folder raw/count.

trans-unit.source: In the modeling section, we show users how to build these count tables for categorical features from scratch, or alternatively to use a pre-built count table for their explorations.
trans-unit.target: In the modeling section, we show users how to build these count tables for categorical features from scratch, or alternatively to use a pre-built count table for their explorations.

trans-unit.source: In what follows, when we refer to "pre-built count tables", we mean using the count tables that we provide.
trans-unit.target: In what follows, when we refer to "pre-built count tables", we mean using the count tables that we provide.

trans-unit.source: Detailed instructions on how to access these tables are below.
trans-unit.target: Detailed instructions on how to access these tables are below.

trans-unit.source: Our model building process in Azure Machine Learning will follow these steps:
trans-unit.target: Our model building process in Azure Machine Learning will follow these steps:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Get the data from Hive tables into Azure Machine Learning</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Get the data from Hive tables into Azure Machine Learning</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create the experiment: clean the data, choose a learner, and featurize with count tables</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create the experiment: clean the data, choose a learner, and featurize with count tables</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Train the model</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Train the model</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Score the model on test data</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Score the model on test data</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Evaluate the model</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Evaluate the model</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish the model as a web-service to be consumed</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish the model as a web-service to be consumed</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Now we are ready to build models in Azure Machine Learning studio.
trans-unit.target: Now we are ready to build models in Azure Machine Learning studio.

trans-unit.source: Our down sampled data is saved as Hive tables in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Our down sampled data is saved as Hive tables in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: We will use the Azure Machine Learning Reader module to read this data.
trans-unit.target: We will use the Azure Machine Learning Reader module to read this data.

trans-unit.source: The credentials to access the storage account of this cluster are provided below.
trans-unit.target: The credentials to access the storage account of this cluster are provided below.

trans-unit.source: Start by selecting a +NEW -> EXPERIMENT -> Blank Experiment.
trans-unit.target: Start by selecting a +NEW -> EXPERIMENT -> Blank Experiment.

trans-unit.source: Then, from the Search box on the top left, search for "Reader".
trans-unit.target: Then, from the Search box on the top left, search for "Reader".

trans-unit.source: Drag and drop the Reader module on to the experiment canvas (the middle portion of the screen) to use the module for data access.
trans-unit.target: Drag and drop the Reader module on to the experiment canvas (the middle portion of the screen) to use the module for data access.

trans-unit.source: This is what the Reader looks like while getting data from the Hive table:
trans-unit.target: This is what the Reader looks like while getting data from the Hive table:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Reader gets data</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Reader gets data</linkText>

trans-unit.source: For the Reader module, the values of the parameters that are provided in the graphic are just examples of the sort of values you will need to provide.
trans-unit.target: For the Reader module, the values of the parameters that are provided in the graphic are just examples of the sort of values you will need to provide.

trans-unit.source: Here is some general guidance on how to fill out the parameter set for the Reader module.
trans-unit.target: Here is some general guidance on how to fill out the parameter set for the Reader module.

trans-unit.source: Choose "Hive query" for Data Source
trans-unit.target: Choose "Hive query" for Data Source

trans-unit.source: In the Hive database query box, a simple SELECT * FROM database\name.your\table\name> - is enough.
trans-unit.target: In the Hive database query box, a simple SELECT * FROM database\name.your\table\name> - is enough.

trans-unit.source: Hcatalog server URI: If your cluster is "abc", then this is simply: https://abc.azurehdinsight.net
trans-unit.target: Hcatalog server URI: If your cluster is "abc", then this is simply: https://abc.azurehdinsight.net

trans-unit.source: Hadoop user account name: The user name chosen at the time of commissioning the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Hadoop user account name: The user name chosen at the time of commissioning the cluster.

trans-unit.source: (NOT the Remote Access user name!)
trans-unit.target: (NOT the Remote Access user name!)

trans-unit.source: Hadoop user account password: The password for the above user name chosen at the time of commissioning the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Hadoop user account password: The password for the above user name chosen at the time of commissioning the cluster.

trans-unit.source: (NOT the Remote Access password!)
trans-unit.target: (NOT the Remote Access password!)

trans-unit.source: Location of output data: Choose "Azure"
trans-unit.target: Location of output data: Choose "Azure"

trans-unit.source: Azure storage account name: The storage account associated with the cluster
trans-unit.target: Azure storage account name: The storage account associated with the cluster

trans-unit.source: Azure storage account key: The key of the storage account associated with the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Azure storage account key: The key of the storage account associated with the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Azure container name: If the cluster name is "abc", then this is simply "abc", usually.
trans-unit.target: Azure container name: If the cluster name is "abc", then this is simply "abc", usually.

trans-unit.source: Once the Reader finishes getting data (you see the green tick on the Module), save this data as a Dataset (with a name of your choice).
trans-unit.target: Once the Reader finishes getting data (you see the green tick on the Module), save this data as a Dataset (with a name of your choice).

trans-unit.source: What this looks like:
trans-unit.target: What this looks like:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Reader save data</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Reader save data</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Right click on the output port of the Reader module.
trans-unit.target: Right click on the output port of the Reader module.

trans-unit.source: This reveals a Save as dataset option and a Visualize option.
trans-unit.target: This reveals a Save as dataset option and a Visualize option.

trans-unit.source: The Visualize option, if clicked, displays 100 rows of the data, along with a right panel that is useful for some summary statistics.
trans-unit.target: The Visualize option, if clicked, displays 100 rows of the data, along with a right panel that is useful for some summary statistics.

trans-unit.source: To save data, simply select Save as dataset and follow instructions.
trans-unit.target: To save data, simply select Save as dataset and follow instructions.

trans-unit.source: To select the saved dataset for use in a machine learning experiment, locate the datasets using the Search box shown below.
trans-unit.target: To select the saved dataset for use in a machine learning experiment, locate the datasets using the Search box shown below.

trans-unit.source: Then simply type out the name you gave the dataset partially to access it and drag the dataset onto the main panel.
trans-unit.target: Then simply type out the name you gave the dataset partially to access it and drag the dataset onto the main panel.

trans-unit.source: Dropping it onto the main panel selects it for use in machine learning modeling.
trans-unit.target: Dropping it onto the main panel selects it for use in machine learning modeling.

trans-unit.source: *IMPORTANT NOTE:* **Do this for both the train and the test datasets.
trans-unit.target: *IMPORTANT NOTE:* **Do this for both the train and the test datasets.

trans-unit.source: Also, remember to use the database name and table names that you gave for this purpose.
trans-unit.target: Also, remember to use the database name and table names that you gave for this purpose.

trans-unit.source: The values used in the figure are solely for illustration purposes.**
trans-unit.target: The values used in the figure are solely for illustration purposes.**

trans-unit.source: Our Azure ML experiment looks like the below:
trans-unit.target: Our Azure ML experiment looks like the below:

trans-unit.source: We now examine the key components of this experiment.
trans-unit.target: We now examine the key components of this experiment.

trans-unit.source: As a reminder, we need to drag our saved train and test datasets on to our experiment canvas first.
trans-unit.target: As a reminder, we need to drag our saved train and test datasets on to our experiment canvas first.

trans-unit.source: The Clean Missing Data module does what its name suggests: it cleans missing data in ways that can be user-specified.
trans-unit.target: The Clean Missing Data module does what its name suggests: it cleans missing data in ways that can be user-specified.

trans-unit.source: Looking into this module, we see this:
trans-unit.target: Looking into this module, we see this:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Clean missing data</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Clean missing data</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Here, we chose to replace all missing values with a 0.
trans-unit.target: Here, we chose to replace all missing values with a 0.

trans-unit.source: There are other options as well, which can be seen by looking at the dropdowns in the module.
trans-unit.target: There are other options as well, which can be seen by looking at the dropdowns in the module.

trans-unit.source: There can be millions of unique values for some categorical features of large datasets.
trans-unit.target: There can be millions of unique values for some categorical features of large datasets.

trans-unit.source: Using naive methods such as one-hot encoding for representing such high-dimensional categorical features is entirely infeasible.
trans-unit.target: Using naive methods such as one-hot encoding for representing such high-dimensional categorical features is entirely infeasible.

trans-unit.source: In this walkthrough, we demonstrate how to use count features using built-in Azure Machine Learning modules to generate compact representations of these high-dimensional categorical variables.
trans-unit.target: In this walkthrough, we demonstrate how to use count features using built-in Azure Machine Learning modules to generate compact representations of these high-dimensional categorical variables.

trans-unit.source: The end-result is a smaller model size, faster training times, and performance metrics that are quite comparable to using other techniques.
trans-unit.target: The end-result is a smaller model size, faster training times, and performance metrics that are quite comparable to using other techniques.

trans-unit.source: To build count features, we use the Build Counting Transform module that is available in Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: To build count features, we use the Build Counting Transform module that is available in Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: The module looks like this :
trans-unit.target: The module looks like this :

trans-unit.source: Important Note : In the Count columns box, we enter those columns that we wish to perform counts on.
trans-unit.target: Important Note : In the Count columns box, we enter those columns that we wish to perform counts on.

trans-unit.source: Typically, these are (as mentioned) high-dimensional categorical columns.
trans-unit.target: Typically, these are (as mentioned) high-dimensional categorical columns.

trans-unit.source: At the start, we mentioned that the Criteo dataset has 26 categorical columns : from Col15 to Col40.
trans-unit.target: At the start, we mentioned that the Criteo dataset has 26 categorical columns : from Col15 to Col40.

trans-unit.source: Here, we count on all of them and give their indices (from 15 to 40 separated by commas as shown).
trans-unit.target: Here, we count on all of them and give their indices (from 15 to 40 separated by commas as shown).

trans-unit.source: To use the module in the MapReduce mode (appropriate for large datasets), we need access to an HDInsight Hadoop cluster (the one used for feature exploration above can be reused for this purpose as well) and its credentials.
trans-unit.target: To use the module in the MapReduce mode (appropriate for large datasets), we need access to an HDInsight Hadoop cluster (the one used for feature exploration above can be reused for this purpose as well) and its credentials.

trans-unit.source: The figures above illustrate what the filled-in values look like (replace the values provided for illustration with those relevant for your own use-case).
trans-unit.target: The figures above illustrate what the filled-in values look like (replace the values provided for illustration with those relevant for your own use-case).

trans-unit.source: In the figure above, we show how to enter the input blob location.
trans-unit.target: In the figure above, we show how to enter the input blob location.

trans-unit.source: This location has the data reserved for building count tables on.
trans-unit.target: This location has the data reserved for building count tables on.

trans-unit.source: After this module finishes running, we can save the transform for later by right clicking on the module and selecting the Save as Transform option:
trans-unit.target: After this module finishes running, we can save the transform for later by right clicking on the module and selecting the Save as Transform option:

trans-unit.source: In our experiment architecture shown above, the dataset "ytransform2" corresponds precisely to a saved count transform.
trans-unit.target: In our experiment architecture shown above, the dataset "ytransform2" corresponds precisely to a saved count transform.

trans-unit.source: For the remainder of this experiment, we assume that the reader used a Build Counting Transform module on some data to generate counts, and can then use those counts to generate count features on the train and test datasets.
trans-unit.target: For the remainder of this experiment, we assume that the reader used a Build Counting Transform module on some data to generate counts, and can then use those counts to generate count features on the train and test datasets.

trans-unit.source: Once we have a count transform ready, the user can choose what features to include in their train and test datasets using the Modify Count Table Parameters module.
trans-unit.target: Once we have a count transform ready, the user can choose what features to include in their train and test datasets using the Modify Count Table Parameters module.

trans-unit.source: We just show this module below for completeness, but in interests of simplicity do not actually use it in our experiment.
trans-unit.target: We just show this module below for completeness, but in interests of simplicity do not actually use it in our experiment.

trans-unit.source: In this case, as can be seen, we have chosen to use just the log-odds and to ignore the back off column.
trans-unit.target: In this case, as can be seen, we have chosen to use just the log-odds and to ignore the back off column.

trans-unit.source: We can also set parameters such as the garbage bin threshold, how many pseudo-prior examples to add for smoothing, and whether to use any Laplacian noise or not.
trans-unit.target: We can also set parameters such as the garbage bin threshold, how many pseudo-prior examples to add for smoothing, and whether to use any Laplacian noise or not.

trans-unit.source: All these are advanced features and it is to be noted that the default values are a good starting point for users who are new to this type of feature generation.
trans-unit.target: All these are advanced features and it is to be noted that the default values are a good starting point for users who are new to this type of feature generation.

trans-unit.source: Now we focus on an important point about transforming our train and test data prior to actually generating count features.
trans-unit.target: Now we focus on an important point about transforming our train and test data prior to actually generating count features.

trans-unit.source: Note that there are two Execute R Script modules used before we apply the count transform to our data.
trans-unit.target: Note that there are two Execute R Script modules used before we apply the count transform to our data.

trans-unit.source: Here is the first R script:
trans-unit.target: Here is the first R script:

trans-unit.source: In this R script, we rename our columns to names "Col1" to "Col40".
trans-unit.target: In this R script, we rename our columns to names "Col1" to "Col40".

trans-unit.source: This is because the count transform expects names of this format.
trans-unit.target: This is because the count transform expects names of this format.

trans-unit.source: In the second R script, we balance the distribution between positive and negative classes (classes 1 ansd 0 respectively) by downsampling the negative class.
trans-unit.target: In the second R script, we balance the distribution between positive and negative classes (classes 1 ansd 0 respectively) by downsampling the negative class.

trans-unit.source: The R script below shows how to do this :
trans-unit.target: The R script below shows how to do this :

trans-unit.source: In this simple R script, we use "pos\neg\ratio" to set the amount of balance between the positive and the negative classes.
trans-unit.target: In this simple R script, we use "pos\neg\ratio" to set the amount of balance between the positive and the negative classes.

trans-unit.source: This is important to do since improving class imbalance usually has performance benefits for classification problems where the class distribution is skewed (recall that in our case, we have 3.3% positive class and 96.7% negative class).
trans-unit.target: This is important to do since improving class imbalance usually has performance benefits for classification problems where the class distribution is skewed (recall that in our case, we have 3.3% positive class and 96.7% negative class).

trans-unit.source: Finally, we can use the Apply Transformation module to apply the count transforms on our train and test datasets.
trans-unit.target: Finally, we can use the Apply Transformation module to apply the count transforms on our train and test datasets.

trans-unit.source: This module takes the saved count transform as one input and the train or test datasets as the other input, and returns data with count features.
trans-unit.target: This module takes the saved count transform as one input and the train or test datasets as the other input, and returns data with count features.

trans-unit.source: It is shown below :
trans-unit.target: It is shown below :

trans-unit.source: It is instructive to see what the count features look like in our case.
trans-unit.target: It is instructive to see what the count features look like in our case.

trans-unit.source: Below, we show an excerpt of this :
trans-unit.target: Below, we show an excerpt of this :

trans-unit.source: In this excerpt, we show that for the columns that we counted on, we get the counts and log odds in addition to any relevant backoffs.
trans-unit.target: In this excerpt, we show that for the columns that we counted on, we get the counts and log odds in addition to any relevant backoffs.

trans-unit.source: We are now ready to build an Azure Machine Learning model using these transformed datasets.
trans-unit.target: We are now ready to build an Azure Machine Learning model using these transformed datasets.

trans-unit.source: In the next section, we show how this can be done.
trans-unit.target: In the next section, we show how this can be done.

trans-unit.source: First, we need to choose a learner.
trans-unit.target: First, we need to choose a learner.

trans-unit.source: We are going to use a two class boosted decision tree as our learner.
trans-unit.target: We are going to use a two class boosted decision tree as our learner.

trans-unit.source: Here are the default options for this learner:
trans-unit.target: Here are the default options for this learner:

trans-unit.source: For our experiment, we simply going to choose the default values.
trans-unit.target: For our experiment, we simply going to choose the default values.

trans-unit.source: We note that the defaults are usually meaningful and a good way to get quick baselines on performance.
trans-unit.target: We note that the defaults are usually meaningful and a good way to get quick baselines on performance.

trans-unit.source: You can improve on performance by sweeping parameters if you choose to once you have a baseline.
trans-unit.target: You can improve on performance by sweeping parameters if you choose to once you have a baseline.

trans-unit.source: For training, we simply invoke a Train Model module.
trans-unit.target: For training, we simply invoke a Train Model module.

trans-unit.source: The two inputs to it are the Two-Class Boosted Decision Tree learner and our train dataset.
trans-unit.target: The two inputs to it are the Two-Class Boosted Decision Tree learner and our train dataset.

trans-unit.source: This is shown below :
trans-unit.target: This is shown below :

trans-unit.source: Once we have a trained model, we are ready to score on the test dataset and to evaluate its performance.
trans-unit.target: Once we have a trained model, we are ready to score on the test dataset and to evaluate its performance.

trans-unit.source: We do this by using the Score Model module shown below, along with an Evaluate Model module :
trans-unit.target: We do this by using the Score Model module shown below, along with an Evaluate Model module :

trans-unit.source: Finally, we would like to analyze model performance.
trans-unit.target: Finally, we would like to analyze model performance.

trans-unit.source: Usually, for two class (binary) classification problems, a good measure is the AUC.
trans-unit.target: Usually, for two class (binary) classification problems, a good measure is the AUC.

trans-unit.source: To visualize this, we hook up the Score Model module to an Evaluate Model module for this.
trans-unit.target: To visualize this, we hook up the Score Model module to an Evaluate Model module for this.

trans-unit.source: Clicking Visualize on the Evaluate Model module yields a graphic like the below:
trans-unit.target: Clicking Visualize on the Evaluate Model module yields a graphic like the below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Evaluate module BDT model</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Evaluate module BDT model</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In binary (or two class) classification problems, a good measure of prediction accuracy is the Area Under Curve (AUC).
trans-unit.target: In binary (or two class) classification problems, a good measure of prediction accuracy is the Area Under Curve (AUC).

trans-unit.source: Below, we show our results using this model on our test dataset.
trans-unit.target: Below, we show our results using this model on our test dataset.

trans-unit.source: To get this, right click the output port of the Evaluate Model module and then Visualize.
trans-unit.target: To get this, right click the output port of the Evaluate Model module and then Visualize.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Visualize Evaluate Model module</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Visualize Evaluate Model module</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The ability to publish an Azure Machine Learning model as web services with a minimum of fuss is a valuable feature for making it widely available.
trans-unit.target: The ability to publish an Azure Machine Learning model as web services with a minimum of fuss is a valuable feature for making it widely available.

trans-unit.source: Once that is done, anyone can make calls to the web service with input data that they need predictions for, and the web service uses the model to return those predictions.
trans-unit.target: Once that is done, anyone can make calls to the web service with input data that they need predictions for, and the web service uses the model to return those predictions.

trans-unit.source: To do this, we first save our trained model as a Trained Model object.
trans-unit.target: To do this, we first save our trained model as a Trained Model object.

trans-unit.source: This is done by right clicking on the Train Model module and using the Save as Trained Model option.
trans-unit.target: This is done by right clicking on the Train Model module and using the Save as Trained Model option.

trans-unit.source: Next, we need to create input and output ports for our web service:
trans-unit.target: Next, we need to create input and output ports for our web service:

trans-unit.source: an input port takes data in the same form as the data that we need predictions for
trans-unit.target: an input port takes data in the same form as the data that we need predictions for

trans-unit.source: an output port returns the Scored Labels and the associated probabilities.
trans-unit.target: an output port returns the Scored Labels and the associated probabilities.

trans-unit.source: It is convenient to use an Apply SQL Transformation module to select just 10 rows to serve as the input port data.
trans-unit.target: It is convenient to use an Apply SQL Transformation module to select just 10 rows to serve as the input port data.

trans-unit.source: Select just these rows of data for our input port using the SQL query shown below.
trans-unit.target: Select just these rows of data for our input port using the SQL query shown below.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Input port data</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Input port data</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Now we are ready to run a small experiment that can be used to publish our web service.
trans-unit.target: Now we are ready to run a small experiment that can be used to publish our web service.

trans-unit.source: As a zeroth step, since the count table is large, we take a few lines of test data and generate output data from it with count features.
trans-unit.target: As a zeroth step, since the count table is large, we take a few lines of test data and generate output data from it with count features.

trans-unit.source: This can serve as the input data format for our webservice.
trans-unit.target: This can serve as the input data format for our webservice.

trans-unit.source: This is shown below:
trans-unit.target: This is shown below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create BDT input data</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create BDT input data</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Note: for the input data format, we will now use the OUTPUT of the Count Featurizer module.
trans-unit.target: Note: for the input data format, we will now use the OUTPUT of the Count Featurizer module.

trans-unit.source: Once this experiment finishes running, save the output from the Count Featurizer module as a Dataset.
trans-unit.target: Once this experiment finishes running, save the output from the Count Featurizer module as a Dataset.

trans-unit.source: Important Note: This Dataset will be used for the input data in the webservice.
trans-unit.target: Important Note: This Dataset will be used for the input data in the webservice.

trans-unit.source: First, we show what this looks like.
trans-unit.target: First, we show what this looks like.

trans-unit.source: The essential structure is a Score Model module that accepts our trained model object and a few lines of input data that we generated in the previous steps using the Count Featurizer module.
trans-unit.target: The essential structure is a Score Model module that accepts our trained model object and a few lines of input data that we generated in the previous steps using the Count Featurizer module.

trans-unit.source: We use "Project Columns" to project out the Scored labels and the Score probabilities.
trans-unit.target: We use "Project Columns" to project out the Scored labels and the Score probabilities.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Project Columns</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Project Columns</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Notice how the Project Columns module can be used for 'filtering' data out from a dataset.
trans-unit.target: Notice how the Project Columns module can be used for 'filtering' data out from a dataset.

trans-unit.source: We show the contents below:
trans-unit.target: We show the contents below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Filtering with the Project Columns module</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Filtering with the Project Columns module</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To get the blue input and output ports, you simply click prepare webservice at the bottom right.
trans-unit.target: To get the blue input and output ports, you simply click prepare webservice at the bottom right.

trans-unit.source: Running this experiment also allows us to publish the web service by clicking the PUBLISH WEB SERVICE icon at the bottom right, shown below.
trans-unit.target: Running this experiment also allows us to publish the web service by clicking the PUBLISH WEB SERVICE icon at the bottom right, shown below.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish Web service</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish Web service</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Once the webservice is published, we get redirected to a page that looks thus:
trans-unit.target: Once the webservice is published, we get redirected to a page that looks thus:

trans-unit.source: We see two links for webservices on the left side:
trans-unit.target: We see two links for webservices on the left side:

trans-unit.source: The REQUEST/RESPONSE Service (or RRS) is meant for single predictions and is what we will utilize in this workshop.
trans-unit.target: The REQUEST/RESPONSE Service (or RRS) is meant for single predictions and is what we will utilize in this workshop.

trans-unit.source: The BATCH EXECUTION Service (BES) is used for batch predictions and requires that the input data used to make predictions reside in Azure Blob Storage.
trans-unit.target: The BATCH EXECUTION Service (BES) is used for batch predictions and requires that the input data used to make predictions reside in Azure Blob Storage.

trans-unit.source: Clicking on the link REQUEST/RESPONSE takes us to a page that gives us pre-canned code in C#, python, and R. This code can be conveniently used for making calls to the webservice.
trans-unit.target: Clicking on the link REQUEST/RESPONSE takes us to a page that gives us pre-canned code in C#, python, and R. This code can be conveniently used for making calls to the webservice.

trans-unit.source: Note that the API key on this page needs to be used for authentication.
trans-unit.target: Note that the API key on this page needs to be used for authentication.

trans-unit.source: It is convenient to copy this python code over to a new cell in the IPython notebook.
trans-unit.target: It is convenient to copy this python code over to a new cell in the IPython notebook.

trans-unit.target: Note that in this case, we chose the default values that the pre-canned code provides (0's for all numeric columns and the string "value" for all categorical columns).

trans-unit.source: This concludes our end-to-end walkthrough showing how to handle large scale dataset using Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: This concludes our end-to-end walkthrough showing how to handle large scale dataset using Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: We started with a terabyte of data, constructed a prediction model and deployed it as a web service in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: We started with a terabyte of data, constructed a prediction model and deployed it as a web service in the cloud.
